text: Behind the main title and the credits:

The hoofprints are deeply etched in the ground, picking t way through scrubby desert growth. An occasional tumblewe drifts with the light breeze across the pattern of prints and lightly-blown soil and sand begin the work of erasing them. The CAMERA FOLLOWING the hoofprints
We see the rider now. BACK TO CAMERA, jogging slowly alon heading down a long valley toward a still-distant ranch h with its outlying barn and corrals.

The CAMERA FRAMES and MOVES with the lone horseman. He is ETHAN EDWARDS, a man as hard as the country he is crossin Ethan is in his forties, with a three-day stubble of bear Dust is caked in the lines of his face and powders his  clothing. He wears a long Confederate overcoat, torn at o pocket, patched and clumsily stitched at the elbows. His trousers are a faded blue with an off-color stripe do the legs where once there had been the yellow stripes of Yankee cavalry. His saddle is Mexican and across it he ca a folded serape in place of the Texas poncho... Rider and horse have come a long way. The CAMERA HOLDS an PANS the rider past and we see another detail; strapped o his saddle roll is a sabre and scabbard with a gray silk  sash wrapped around it... Horse and rider pass, moving cl to the ranch as a little girl and a small dog come tearin around the corner of the house.

location: THE YARD OF THE EDWARDS RANCH

text: She is staring wide-eyed at the distant horseman o.s. Her little dog has seen him too and is barking excitedly. DEBBIE quickly reaches to grab the dog by the scruff of t neck, crouching over him. Debbie is 11 years old with a  piquant, memorable face.

Here we must establish and dramatize what it is about her face that is memorable, so that if we were to see her aga five or six years later, we would know it is she -- perha the eye color or the slant of eyebrow, or a trick of  scratching bridge of nose with crooked forefinger.

The ranch house is of adobe, solidly built, with a sod an cross-timbered roof, deep windows. A small gallery or por extends across the front. AARON EDWARDS comes through the door, attracted by the dog's barking -- and then he, too, sees the approaching horseman and comes farther out -- cu but not at all apprehensive. Aaron is a lean, weathered a tired man, with a down-swept mustache; a gentler-looking than Ethan and possibly a few years older. As he squints off, studying the rider, his older daughter LUCY, comes out to stand behind him. Lucy is from 16 to 1 a pleasant, feminine girl. She is carrying a mixing bowl  with some sort of batter in it, which she now completely  forgets to whip in her interest in the approaching strang In the next instant MARTHA EDWARDS follows the daughter o the porch. Martha is a still-lovely woman, although the y have etched fine wrinkles about her eyes and mouth, and w has worn and coarsened her hands. Those hands will never idle when Martha is on scene... And now, while she shares the family's interest in the approaching horseman, she  automatically notes that Lucy has forgotten her task -- a she takes the mixing bowl from her and stirs the batter.

Along the side of the house comes BEN EDWARDS, 14, with a man-sized armload of chunkwood clutched to his chest. He, too, has spotted the stranger and is all attention. So mu so that he trips, but recovers his footing. He pauses to  dump the wood into a woodbox by the door -- his eyes alwa riveted on the oncoming rider -- and then he moves toward the others, biting a splinter out of a finger. Beyond Ben MARTIN PAULEY emerges from the barn and crosses the open  ground heading toward CAMERA. Martin is somewhat under 20 lithe, perfectly coordinated male animal, with Indian-str hair and a white man's eyes. He is carrying bridle or oth horse-gear. He looks to the family on the porch -- to see they recognize the stranger -- then out again. He continu followed by Ben, toward where Debbie crouches over her dog.
As he rides downslope toward the house. THE CREDITS END.

Suddenly, Martha's eyes widen as she -- even before Aaron recognizes the distant rider. Her hand goes to her mouth check the name that trembles on her lips... An instant la Aaron, too, identifies the oncoming horseman.
(incredulous) Ethan?
He looks at her, frowning, then slowly steps out onto the hard ground. Martha hands the bowl back to Lucy and follo Aaron.

location: THE YARD OF THE EDWARDS HOUSE

text: as Ethan rides in and sits his horse, looking down at the There is a noticeable constraint on all of them. Finally:
Hello, Aaron...
His eyes shift to Martha and hold. Ethan is, and always h been, in love with his brother's wife and she with him.
Martha...
(a bit shakily) Hello, Ethan.
Ethan slowly, stiffly swings out of the saddle. Aaron and Martha exchange quick glances... troubled, puzzled. Aaron pastes on an uncertain smile as Ethan comes around his ho toward their side.
How's California?
How should I know?
But Mose Harper said...
That old goat still creakin'  around?... Whyn't someone bury him?

He goes to his saddle pack, begins unlacing it. Ben and D have inched closer -- half-shy, half-curious. Debbie's dog begins sniffing at his heels. Ethan looks do at them - not unfriendly, just a man not used to children
Ben, ain't you?
Ben nods.
(frowning at Debbie) Lucy, you ain't much bigger than  when I saw you last.
I'm Deborah! (pointing) She's Lucy.
Ethan looks in the direction of the pointing finger.
as Lucy steps down from the porch and approaches.
Lucy's going on seventeen now...
An' she's got a beau! Kisses him,  too!
That's enough... Go on inside and  help Lucy set the table... You, too,  Deborah!
as Martin -- with slightly averted face -- crosses to tak the bridle of Ethan's horse and lead him away.
(wheeling on him) MOMENTO!
Martin checks his stride, stares in surprise.
(contritely) Martin!... Here we've been standing...  Ethan, you haven't forgotten Martin?
Oh... Mistook you for a half-breed.
(levelly) Not quite... Quarter Cherokee. The  rest is Welsh... So they tell me.
You've done a lot of growin'...
It was Ethan found you squallin' in  a sage clump after your folks was  massacred...
(bluntly) It just happened to be me... No need  to make any more of it...
I'll take care of your horse for  you, Uncle Ethan.
Again, he starts to lead away.
Hold on!
Martin stops again.
I'll take this...

He completes unlacing the pack and takes it -- treating i as though it contained something of value. Martin watches with a touch of resentment: Ethan doesn't trust him. Ethan turns and sees the look. He doesn't care what Marti thinks, nor does he explain. Martin leads the horse off.
Supper'll be ready by the time you  wash up... Let me take your coat for  you, Ethan.
He hesitates, then grudgingly surrenders it -- conscious its sorry condition.
(smiling faintly) And... welcome home.
He just nods, then turns to follow Aaron around the side the house toward the wash-up.
She stands alone, looking after Ethan -- his coat in her  arms. She holds it against her breast for just a moment a her eyes are tender.

The family is finishing dinner -- and the scene is not qu but almost, a still-life. Loud in the room is the pendulu tick of a Seth-Thomas clock on the mantel above the firep in which logs are burning briskly. Ben crouches near the  fireplace, fascinatedly examining the scabbard and sabre  Ethan has brought home from the wars. He tries to ease the blade just a bit out of its scabbard Aaron sits at one end of the hand-hewn table, Martha at t other. At her right is Ethan, his fork scraping the last  crumb off his plate. Lucy sits at her father's right and  Martin at his left. Next to Martin is Debbie. In the cent of the table is the sorry remnant of what was once a meal Lucy and Martin have finished eating. Aaron is sipping hi coffee, and Martha -- her own plate largely untasted -- i watching Ethan. Ethan has shaved, changed his shirt. He straightens  contentedly and every eye is on him, expectantly.
Good.
The clock rattles alarmingly -- the usual preliminary to striking; and then it bangs out the strokes like a fire-a gong. Eight fast clangs.
Ben! Deborah! Bed!
But I've got to help with the dishes.
Not tonight... Ben, put that sword  back.
It's not a sword, ma... it's a saber! (moving to Ethan) Did you kill many damYankees with  this sabre, Uncle Ethan?
(matter-of-factly) Some...
How many damYankees, Uncle Ethan?
Ben!... Martin, he'll sleep in the  bunkhouse with you tonight.
Martin nods and crosses to kiss Martha good night.
Good night, Aunt Martha... Uncle  Aaron... (he hesitates) Good night, Uncle Ethan.
Ethan doesn't like being called Uncle -- as we must know  from the quick look he shoots at Martin. But he acknowled it.
Night.
Ben reluctantly puts the scabbard away, turns to Ethan.
Will you tell me tomorrow about the  war?
The war ended three years ago, boy!
It did?... Then whyn't you come home before now?
BEN!... Go 'long with Martin. MARCH!
As Ben reluctantly heads out with Martin, Deborah crosses Ethan's side and studies him gravely.
Lucy's wearing the gold locket you  gave her when she was a little girl...
Oh?
She don't wear it much account of it  makes her neck green.
(aghast) Deborah!
(defensively) Well, it does... But I wouldn't care  if you gave me a gold locket if it  made my neck green or not.
Ethan looks at her gravely.
'Fraid I... (then he remembers  something, rises) Wait.
He crosses to where his pack is -- a side table or someth and burrows into it. Debbie is at his side.
How about this?
It is a gold medal or medallion -- something appropriate Maximilian of Mexico -- suspended by a long multi-colored satin ribbon.
Oh! LOOK! My gold locket!
She holds it high for mother -- and all -- to see. Martha takes it and reacts at its weight.
It's solid gold... Ethan, I don't  think she's old enough...
Let her keep it... Just something I  picked up in Mexico.
Martha reluctantly surrenders it to Debbie's eager hand. Aaron hasn't missed the word "Mexico" and looks sharply a Ethan.
Oh, thank you, Uncle Ethan...
(to Debbie) Come along...

The two girls leave the main room. Martha and Aaron both  look at Ethan -- half expecting some further explanation. He turns from them and looks into the fire. Martha begins clear the table. Aaron gets up, takes a pipe and a spill lights it at the fire.
Passed the Todd place comin' in... What happened to 'em?
They gave up... went back to the  cotton rows... So'd the Jamisons... Without Martha, I don't know... She  wouldn't let a man quit.
Ethan turns and looks at her -- still busy with her dishe
(change of tone) Ethan, I could see it in you before  the war... (Ethan looks at him) You wanted to clear out!
Martha freezes in what she's doing -- listening.
And you stayed out beyond all need  to... WHY?
Ethan can't answer, but he takes it as a challenge and al welcomes it.
(hard) You askin' me to clear out now?
(straightening --  with grave dignity) You're my brother... You're welcome  to stay as long as you got a mind  to... Ain't that so, Martha?
(almost a whisper) Of course he is.
I expect to pay my own way...

Martha resumes her activity. Ethan crosses to his pack,  reaches into it for a leather pouch, brings it back and t it onto the table. It lands with a resonant clink. Both Martha and Aaron draw close to the table. (NOTE TO WINTON HOCH: This scene should be dramatically b lighted.)
There's sixty double eagles in  there... twelve-hundred dollars.
He opens a waistline shirt button and hauls out a leather money belt and drops that on the table.
An' twice that in here.
He reaches into the belt and takes out a few mint-fresh g pieces which he slides across the table.
...only these got the late Emperor  Maximilian's picture on 'em.
Martha picks up one of the gold pieces, staring at the fa on the coin: the same as that on the medal -- staring sha then at Ethan. Aaron is examining another coin with a  different interest.
Mint fresh... not a mark on 'em.
He glances questioningly at Ethan.
So?

Aaron shrugs and crosses to a barrel chair. He raises the seat and lifts out a pair of old boots, some rags of clot and then raises a false-bottom lid and drops pouch and mo belt into it. Carefully he replaces everything. During th Ethan's attention has gone to Martha's hand, to one cut  finger, its wound barely healed. He takes the hand -- gen
Cut yourself?
She nods and withdraws the hand.
(softly) You were always hurting about your  hands.

She looks quickly at him and self-consciously tries to hi her hands, conscious of their work-worn appearance. Then for a moment their eyes meet and hold -- and a world sadness and hopelessness is in the look. Aaron closes the seat of the barrel chair.
Time for bed...
He picks up one of the lamps and starts away toward their bedroom door. Martha looks at Ethan again. His expression bitter.
Night, Ethan... Come 'long, Martha.

She turns obediently and follows Aaron. Ethan looks after them and waits as Aaron opens the bedroom door. Martha go into it and Aaron follows and closes the door. Ethan crosses to the lamp on the mantel, blows it out. Only the firelight strikes his face as he stares brooding at the closed bedroom door.
Debbie's dog is barking excitedly as six horsemen slowly  ride toward the house and dismount. A lamp goes on inside

CAPTAIN, THE REVEREND SAM CLAYTON, a big man with frosty  blue eyes, graying hair, a bristly full mustache and the of grave and resolute authority. He is a minister of the  Gospel with a .44 on his hip. LARS JORGENSEN, the Edwards' neighbor, is a harried littl man, Scandinavian. As we shall find out soon, he has a br and buxom wife and a rather astonishing brood of children BRAD JORGENSEN is one of these: sandy-haired, brash, amia impulsive. He is in his early twenties. CHARLIE MacCORRY, slightly older than Brad, is Sergeant o Company A of the Rangers. (He is also Company A.) Charlie a taciturn, gently-spoken, competent man, clearly pattern by his association with Captain, the Rev. Sam. MOSE HARPER is an old scout -- a walking bone-rack, yet  capable of tireless feats of endurance. Some think him  "tetched" yet he has managed to endure to his age during time and in a region where few men lived to see their  grandchildren. He wears a ragged dark overcoat in all wea a narrow-brimmed hat with a feather in its band. ED NESBY is a rancher and homesteader in his mid-thirties resolute, honest, self-effacing; nothing picturesque or  dramatic about him; just a solid citizen and a realist.

She is at the window of her bedroom, wrapper clutched wit one hand, lamp upraised in the other as she stares into t dawn to see who these callers are. We hear the heavy foot falls of the approaching men, then a loud knock thrice  repeated -- an ominous sound.
Aaron! Open up!... Sam Clayton!
The door is opened by Aaron -- holding a lamp and a gun. is only partly dressed -- pants, boots, undershirt. The b of light slashes across the faces of Sam and some of the behind him.
Reverend... Come in!
Sorry to get you out of bed so  early... (as Martha enters,  tightening her wrapper) Mornin', Sister Edwards.
What is it, Reverend?
Lars Jorgensen claims someone bust  into his corral last night and run  off his best cows...
You mean those pure breds he just  bought?
Jorgensen enters -- an angry little man -- closely follow by Mose Harper, who is grinning foolishly.
Next time I raise pigs, by golly!   You never hear of anyone running off  pigs, I bet you.
Injuns has 'em... Caddoes or Kiowas... Kiowas or Caddoes.
(irritably) Caddoes!
Mose spots Martha and at once whips off his hat and makes her an exaggerated cavalier's bow.
Respects to a charmin' lady, ma'am. ...Respects, respects...
Ed Nesby enters.
Mornin'...
Coffee's made if you...
Coffee'd be fine, sister...
She heads for the stove.
(an old man's whimper) My bones is cold...
His eyes brighten as he looks toward the fire and spots a rocking chair. He shuffles toward it, plants himself and  begins rocking and half-crooning to himself.
Or bumble bees, by golly... I show  them dirty rustlers!
(crooning) Lookit me, old Mose Harper, rockin'  in a rockin' chair... I'm a-goin' to  set 'n rock, 'n rock, 'n rock, 'n  rock...
The front door opens to admit Martin, fully dressed and a with Charlie MacCorry.
Over here, Martin... Aaron...
Martin ranges himself next to Aaron and both face Clayton
Raise your right hands.

Martha sets out cups on the table, begins pouring the cof During the swearing-in, Ethan will enter the room from th inner door -- unnoticed by the other men, but not by Mart And as the scene plays, the audience must always be consc of the by-play of glances between Martha and Ethan as the face the prospect of being left in this house together.

You are hereby volunteer privates in  Company A of the Texas Rangers and  will faithfully discharge the duties  of same without recompense or monetary  compensation -- meaning no pay!...  Amen and get your shirt on, will  you, Aaron.
(stubbornly) Ain't goin' volunteerin' after  rustlers without my morning coffee,  Reverend... Drink your own!
(sternly -- as he  reaches for his cup) From now on, call me 'Captain'!
But Ethan advances and calmly appropriates the cup Clayto is reaching for...
(mockingly) Captain the Reverend Samuel Johnson  Clayton!... Mighty impressive.
Clayton marks his surprise.
(dourly) Well... the prodigal brother... When'd you get back?
Ethan sips his coffee and doesn't answer.
Haven't seen you since the surrender. (a pause) Come to think of it, I didn't see  you at the surrender.
I don't believe in surrenderin'... I  still got my sabre, Reverend... never  turned it into any ploughshare  neither!
Is no time for kaffee-klatch while a  man's beef is been run off.
Injuns, Ethan... (taps his nose) Caddoes or Kiowas... Mose Harper,  drinkin' coffee in a rockin' chair. ...ay-eh!
Martha has left the room briefly to fetch Aaron's shirt a vest and stands behind him. Aaron drains his cup.
Ethan, countin' on you to look after  things while I'm gone.

Ethan -- cup to his lips -- looks over its rim at Martha Aaron starts to put on his shirt. Their eyes meet briefly then she looks away. Ethan sloshes the dregs of his cup i the fire -- some of it spattering Mose.
You ain't goin'...
He sure is goin'... He's sworn in.
(angrily) Well, swear him out again!... I'll  go with you.
Martha stands submissively, with her head bent, eyes aver as Ethan crosses the room to get his coat, guns, etc. Aar follows him.
Now, Ethan, I ain't sure...
Don't argue!... And stay close... Maybe they're rustlers... and maybe  this dodderin' old idiot ain't so  far wrong...
Thankin' ye, Ethan... thankin' ye. Kind words...
(grudgingly) All right... I'll swear you in...
You can forget that... (as Sam stares) Wouldn't be legal anyway.
Why? (a pause -- then  shrewdly) You wanted for a crime, Ethan?
Martha waits -- intent.
You askin' as a Reverend or a Captain,  Sam?
I'm askin' as a Ranger of the  sovereign state of Texas.
Got a warrant?
You fit a lot of descriptions.
(levelly) I figger a man's only good for one  oath at a time... I took mine to the  Confederate States of America... (he pauses -- then) So did you, Reverend...
He looks past him then -- at Martha and then at Aaron.
Stick close, Aaron...
He looks at Martha again... and then strides out.

As Ethan emerges he is brought to a momentary halt by sig of a couple -- Brad and Lucy -- in each other's arms, sta near the saddled horses of the posse. Clayton and Jorgens following him out, spot the couple, who now belatedly are conscious of their audience.
Brad!... Is no time for lolly- gagging...

In confusion, Lucy runs back around the side of the house Brad -- unrepentant -- grins at his irascible old man and heads for his waiting horse. Clayton chuckles and turns t Martha, who has followed them out.
Looks like I'll be reading the lines  over that pair before long, sister  Edwards.
Is no time for talking weddings... Better say prayers for those dirty  thieves, by golly... running off a  man's beef...
Mose, last to emerge, bows elaborately to Martha.
Grateful to the hospitality of yore  rockin' chair, ma'am...
The men are mounting. Mose nimbly vaults onto the back of his horse -- which he rides bareback, with only a blanket pad.
as Ethan and Martin ride to join the group.
Let's get on with it...
WAIT!
She comes flying out of the house in her long flannel nig and runs to Martin.
Martin! Ride me as far as the well!
Grab hold!...

He swings her up in front of his saddle. They start away. Ethan is last to ride out. He is watching Martha. He brin a gloved hand up in a salute. She starts to raise her han but only brings it just above her waist, a fluttering ges with tremulous fingers. It is the last he will ever see o her alive.
as the posse slowly rides out, with Ethan last. Martin re in to let Debbie slip to the ground. Ethan passes her. Debbie stands watching the men ride away, waving at them.
(calling) DEBORAH!
She turns and comes running back -- CAMERA PANNING -- to little group on the porch; Ben in the door; Lucy crossing the porch; Aaron and Martha at the steps.

Ethan and Mose are advancing at a steady walk, both men  leaning slightly out of their saddles to study the terrai the trail they are following. Out to one side -- fifty ya distant -- is the main body of the posse: Sam, Jorgensen, Charlie, Ed, moving roughly parallel to Ethan but at a fa clip. Martin comes riding in toward Ethan from behind CAM
(calling) Uncle Ethan!
Ethan reins in -- compressing his lips at the "Uncle." Mose waits.
Somethin' mighty fishy about this  trail, Uncle Ethan...
Stop callin' me 'uncle'... I ain't  your uncle.
Yes, sir.
Don't have to call me 'sir' neither... Nor grampaw neither... Nor Methuselah  neither... I can whup you to a  frazzle.
Mose lets out a snickering laugh.
What you want me to call you?
Name's Ethan... Now what's so mighty  fishy about this trail?
Well, fust off...
He breaks and all turn at a distant hail from Jorgensen.
Look! Look!
He is holding his rifle with both hands straight over his head -- and he repeats the signal until he sees they have seen him.
(excitedly) Brad! He's found them... Come on!
as Jorgensen digs spurs and leads the way. The other ride follow.
He waits grimly until he sees them coming, then wheels hi mount and takes off over the hill.

as it comes up the rise and the men rein in on the crest. Jorgensen stares and his face mirrors shock and dismay. The other men look down into the long valley on the far s with equally grim expressions.
Call that young fool back!

Jorgensen doesn't even seem to hear him. Angrily Ethan wh out revolver and fires into the air. Then he swings his a in a come-back gesture. He rides out ahead then a short  distance and dismounts... and slowly the others follow. We see now, the bodies of a few bulls stiffening in the s Ethan goes to the nearest one. A feathered lance is drive into it. He pulls the lance out. Mose comes over beside h
(angrily) Caddo or Kiowa, huh?... Ain't but  one tribe uses a lance like that!
He hands the lance to Mose.
(almost a whisper) Ay-he... Comanch!
Brad rides in -- shrill with anger.
Killed every one -- an' not for food  either... Why'd they do a thing like  that?
Stealing the cattle was just to pull  us out... This here's a murder raid... (facing Jorgensen) It shapes up to scald out either  your place... or my brother's.
Jorgensen wilts and casts an anguished look back over the miles they have ridden.
Mama!... Oh please... please no... BRAD!
And with that one word, Jorgensen calls upon his son to f and they take off... fast. Ed Nesby and Charlie MacCorry  follow. Sam Clayton pauses.
Jorgensen's place is closest... If  they're not there, we'll come straight  on!
Then he too rides. Martin swings his horse back to where  Ethan and Mose still are standing.
Well, come on!
Easy! (he starts toward his  horse) It's forty miles, sonny... Horses  can do with some grain and a little  rest.
Comanch generally hits at moonrise.
Moonrise!... It'll be midnight  before... I ain't waitin'...!
He wheels his horse and goes tearing to catch up with the others. Ethan shrugs and stoically takes grain bag to fee his horse. Mose does the same.
Wisht it was Caddoes... or Kiowas... (shakes his head) Comanche...
Ethan just gives him an angry look and then ruthlessly be discarding every bit of unnecessary equipment from his sa
Nothing moves. Nothing could be more tranquil. The shadow are long. A thin wisp of smoke rises from the chimney. An then Debbie's little dog trots around the side of the hou out into the yard.
He comes to a standstill and his nose is working. He begi to make excited little sounds deep in his belly. Then he lies down, muzzle between his paws, watching,  listening.

Debbie sits on the floor, playing with a little rag doll. The slanting blaze of the setting sun makes a brilliant a of light in which she is sitting. Beyond her, on the porc steps, Ben is squatting, whittling a piece of pine into a slingshot frame. We hear Martha and Lucy busy with the di Aaron comes from behind CAMERA and stands in the doorway, absently rapping out his pipe. Near the doorway, on a woo peg, hangs his gun, belt. He puts the pipe in his pocket glances down at Deborah, intent on her play. He looks swi at where the women are busy - then stealthily eases the g from its holster and slides it under his shirt. He hasn't made a sound and is sure he's got away with it. He clears his throat noisily and reaches for a light shot pegged above the door.
Think I'll see if I can pick off a  sage-hen or two, Martha...
busy at the wooden sink. Martha doesn't turn.
You do that, Aaron...
(still pleased with  himself) Won't go far...
He steps out. Only then does Martha turn -- and her
and FRAMING the empty holster, as Aaron pauses on the por
My, the days are getting shorter!
as Lucy heads for the lamp.
(sharply) Lucy!... We don't need the lamp yet...
Lucy frowns at her mother.
(easily) Let's enjoy the dusk a while.
Aaron is slowly scanning the terrain.
(to Ben) Mind you sweep up them shavin's.
Yes, Pa... (undertone -- man to  man) An' if you see any sage-hens, I'm  ready.
Aaron stares as the boy shifts a fold of blanket, or what by his side -- to disclose Ethan's cavalry sabre. Aaron s and rubs the youngster's head, then sets out across the y
Debbie's dog rises at Aaron's approach and joins his mast as they set out across the plain.

He is walking through the scrub and brush grass, every se alive and straining. He pauses every three or four stride casting each quadrant in turn. Once he whips, gun ready, a sage-hen or quail whirrs up not far from him. He smiles grimly as he watches it fly away. He keeps on.
Martha comes to stand in the doorway. Ben doesn't look at her. His eyes -- like hers -- are fixed on the figure of man.
(quietly) It's all right, ma... I been  watchin'...  Only I wish...
(quietly) What, Ben?
I wish Uncle Ethan was here. Don't  you, ma?
She doesn't answer. Lucy comes to the door.
Mother, I can't see what I'm doing!...
NOT YET, LUCY!...

He stands on the near slope of a rise and then gradually  moves toward its summit, so that only head will be  silhouetted. He drops to one knee, half-leaning against t slope and slowly looks out... The CAMERA PANS very slowly following his careful sweep of the terrain. The scene is entirely peaceful.
with narrowed eyes slowly scanning the ground. Suddenly t head whips right. We hear a bird's sharp call.
It is taking flight, sweeping away in erratic arcs.
He squints closely at the ground from which the bird had  flown. Then slowly his eyes range toward the left.

Across the meadow, a shadow seems to touch the grass and once a covey of quail takes off, whirring loud. Aaron wai no longer, but slides down the slope and starts running a crouch for the house, stopping every so often to look  backward.

NOTE TO W. HOCH: What J.F. has in mind for this and the  following scenes is the same kind of dramatic use of red achieved in "Yellow Ribbon" in the scene telling of Custe defeat. They are standing in the ruddy glare of the sunset and Be has Ethan's sabre in his hand. We hear Aaron coming at a  run, breathing hard. Ben takes a step as though to go to  him, but Martha's hand at once is on his shoulder. Aaron  gains the porch.
In the house, boy... and...

He puts finger to his lips, sign for Ben to say nothing. Ben nods and goes inside. Aaron and Martha face each othe the question large on her face. Slowly he nods the  confirmation of her fears, then gently propels her ahead him through the door.

The room is deeply shadowed except where the dull crimson the sun through door and windows slashes the blackness. Ben is waiting and Martha turns toward Aaron as he pulls door shut, bars it and sets the shotgun down. He takes th revolver from his waist and Martha holds it as he reaches for his gun belt.
Ben, close the shutters.
Buckling on his gun belt, he moves toward the middle of t room, looking around him, taking inventory of his resourc Lucy slowly approaches, biting a knuckle, eyes wide with  fright.
Pa?
One shutter closes and the bar of light they were standin in goes out. Martha, Aaron and Lucy are dark silhouettes against the red beam from another window.
(sudden fear) Where's Deborah?... (calling it) DEBORAH!
Debbie emerges from a shadowed corner into a beam of ligh She is clutching her rag doll, nibbling a cookie. She hol it for them to see.
I only took one, ma... Topsy was  hungry.
Ben closes the shutter. And now the room is almost comple blacked out, except for the dying light filtering through the rifle ports of the closed shutters.

This should be an expansive view to convey the fact that posse has split -- the main group heading for the Jorgens place, Martin forking off to race alone for the Edwards r Coming toward and passing CAMERA is Martin, riding all ou Several hundred yards away and moving in a divergent dire are the others -- Brad and Charlie, Sam, Jorgensen and Ed Nesby. The men are not compactly bunched, but strung out, each taking his own best course and his own speed... As t riders pass and the dust of their passing, we see two oth riders -- Ethan and Mose -- minute specks in the distance possibly a mile or two behind.

(NOTE TO W. HOCH: What we are trying to get here is that  moment of swift transition from twilight to night; of rid briefly touched with the last colors of day and then, as  they pass, becoming one with blue shadows of night.) Ethan and Mose are holding their mounts to a jog, in mark contrast to the all-out pace of the others. The CAMERA PA after them as the dark fingers of the night stretch acros the valley. The wind begins to rise and somewhere off in hills a coyote pack yaps.

location: ANGLING PAST AARON AT WINDOW INTO ROOM -

text: Aaron is little more than a shadowy silhouette as he peer into the night through a partly-opened shutter. Suddenly room leaps alight as Lucy opens an inner door and enters, holding a lighted lamp. Aaron closes the shutter, spins o her angrily.
LUCY!

Martha crosses the room swiftly and blows out the lamp. In the brief moment the room has been lighted, we see tha Lucy is carrying a dark shawl in one hand; that Ben is  crouched at another window -- rifle ready; and that Debor is on her feet -- standing like a child who is being dres
I'm sorry... I couldn't find the  shawl...
Hurry, Martha... Moon's fixin' to  rise...
He cautiously swings the shutters open. A pale light filt into the room. We see Martha wrapping the shawl around  Deborah.
(softly to the child) We're going to play the sleep-out  game... Remember?... Where you hide  out with grandma?
Where's she buried?
And you'll go along the ditch -- very quietly -- like a... (her voice breaks)
Like a little mouse.
Now!
He reaches for the child, but he has to wait for Martha's last embrace.
There!... And you won't come back or  make a sound... no matter what you  hear? Promise!... No matter what?
I promise... Wait!
Child, child!
Can't I have Topsy to keep me company?
There's no time...
Here she is, baby... Baby...
Aaron takes the child, swings her out the window.
Down low -- go!

Martha would come to the window to look out, but Aaron ba her with an arm and draws back to the side of the window watch her go... Outside the little dog barks a welcome an presumably starts to follow the girl. Aaron reacts.
(hoarse whisper) Here dog... here!
The dog whines but obeys. Aaron continues watching the ch course -- unconsciously imitating her every run and twist Then he smiles and we may see the brightness in the corne of his eyes.
She reached the ditch...
He closes the shutters and turns -- and his arms go aroun Martha, weeping soundlessly.
She'll be all right, mother... she'll  be all right.

Nothing stirs and we hear nothing. Then, with faintest li rustle, Debbie comes snaking along the ground into the ho between the two graves and lies there face down, pressed  against Topsy. She becomes one with the earth and the  stillness. And then the moonlight strikes the tips of the scrub growth and as a cloud scuds by, the moonlight revea something glittering -- like beads. And the CAMERA from t ground-level shot

The Comanche we are later to know as SCAR is painted for tall, savage, mockingly looking down at what we know is t child's hiding place... And in that instant, from a dozen quarters and a dozen throats, sounds the wild yammer of t warwhoop!

He stands beside his spent and fallen horse. Its breathin is a rasping whistle. Martin tries to haul its head up. Useless. Breathing hard himself, his face ashen in the  moonlight, Martin looks desperately off in the direction the ranch. Then he jerks the rifle from its saddle scabba struggling with it because it is under the horse. He free then -- listening... And we hear the steady beat of two  horsemen approaching. Martin knows who they are and his f is alive with hope. He gets the rifle free at last and go running toward the oncoming riders.
(shouting) Ethan!... Ethan!
The CAMERA SWINGS with him and we see Ethan and Mose  approaching at the same steady gait.
(waving) Uncle Ethan... it's me... Martin!
Ethan doesn't slacken, nearly rides him down.
Out of my way!
Martin goes sprawling to his hands and knees. Mose contin without slowing.
(desperately) Mose! Wait!...
He goes running, stumbling after the riders -- desperatel calling to them...
Ethan!... Mose!...
And then at the crest of the rising ground, he stops -- We see in the distance the glow of a fire leading from th barns and the hayricks and the house of Aaron Edwards. Martin runs down the slope.

location: YARD AND APPROACH TO EDWARDS HOUSE

text: (NOTE TO W. HOCH: Here again that use of red is suggested The ANGLE is past the porch uprights toward Mose and Etha as they ride in. Little tongues of fire are licking the e of the uprights. A few arrows, imbedded in the wood, are  burning along their shafts. Beyond are the glowing ashes the hayricks and the charred, smouldering rails of the co There are no bodies in evidence... The red glow of the bu is on the faces of the men as they dismount. Ethan strides to the porch, knocking away one of the blaz arrows as he heads to the door. He stops there -- and wha he sees makes the big shoulders droop, the huge frame slu Slowly then -- and removing his hat -- he goes in. Mose  shuffles to the edge of the porch and squats there and ro back and forth, his face working and crying soundlessly w senile grief. We hear a splintered door crash from its hi within the room and Ethan's muffled voice calling through the house:
Lucy?... Deborah? Lucy?

He strides back through the main room and out onto the po just as Martin comes at a shambling run across the yard. Ethan takes a few steps out toward him. Martin would pass him, but Ethan grabs his arm.
(harshly) You stay out!
Martin tries to fight his arm free.
Nothing for you to see.
Leggo...
Ethan turns him and drives a brutal right to his jaw. Mar goes down -- out cold. And only now do we understand how  merciful the blow was as Ethan looks compassionately at t fallen figure.
Don't let him go in there, Mose...
And he takes off at a stumbling run for the hilltop.

location: THE HILLOCK WITH THE TWO HEADBOARDS

text: as he nears the graves.
(calling) Lucy -- Lucy!

He runs in, looking around him. He sees the little dog, d on the ground. And then he sees a shadowed something: The shawl Debbie had worn. It is spread out, almost as th concealing a body. Fearfully he stoops and pulls it away. There is nothing there, but the shawl. He drops to his kn his head bowed, his face tortured. The moonlight is clear the face of the nearer headboard. It is of weathered wood and the chiselled letters on it read:
a good WIFE & MOTHER In her 41st year

The funeral is begun. In the foreground are three newly- made crosses at the head of as many open graves -- which need not see. With head bared, Sam Clayton is concluding prayer. Near him stand the Jorgensen family: Mrs.  Jorgen Lars and LAURIE -- blonde, just beginning to reach her  maturity -- and a stepping-stone of tow-headed children.
...and to Your keeping we commend  the souls of Aaron... Martha... and  Benjamin Edwards...

Mrs. Jorgensen and Laurie -- impelled by the same feminin sympathy and interest -- turn to look at Ethan and Martin The PANNING CAMERA picks them up...Ethan standing dry-eye looking at the grave of Martha; Martin -- with bruised li looking out across the plain. Clayton now opens his small, well-worn Bible to a marked  page.
Man that is born of woman is of few  days and full of trouble...
Ethan looks at him, angrily, impatiently.
He cometh forth like a...
(harshly) Amen!... Put an 'amen' to it!
...like a flower and is cut down... Amen!
Amen!

Ethan turns on his heel and walks -- CAMERA PANNING -- to where Ed Nesby has been holding the horses. Brad is alrea mounting. Mose is there too and Charlie MacCorry.  Silhou against the dawn light are the rifles in each man's saddl scabbard. Clayton is right behind Ethan.
Charlie--you and Brad ride point! ...Don't get too far ahead...
The young riders spur out.
Ethan is about to mount when Mrs. Jorgensen comes up and  catches his arm.
Ethan... (he turns impatiently) Those girls mean as much to me as  though they were my own... Maybe you  don't know my Brad's been sittin' up  with Lucy... and my Laurie's real  fond of Martin...
Ethan glances back at where Martin and Laurie are standin

The girl is looking at Martin full of compassion, tries t console him by taking his arm and squeezing it as he star blindly at the graves and Jorgensen stolidly beginning th work of shovelling them full.

head_text.ToD: ETHAN AND MRS. JORGENSEN AS BEFORE

text: Ethan looks back at her -- stone-faced.
(impatiently) I'd be obliged if you'd get to the  point, ma'am.
I am... I am... It's just that I  know Martha'd want you to think of  her boys as well as her girls... And  if the girls are... dead... Ethan,  don't let the boys waste their lives  in vengeance!
Ethan shrugs his arm free and mounts.
Promise me, Ethan!
He ignores her and turns angrily to where Martin is.
(harshly) Come on, if you're comin'...
He digs spurs and rides out with the others. Martin comes over, with Laurie a step behind. His face is set, his eye almost unseeing.
(a heartbroken murmur) Oh, Martin... Martin...
We'll find them, Mrs. Jorgensen... We'll find them...

He swings into his saddle. Laurie impulsively runs to his side, steps onto the toe of his stirruped boot and pulls  herself up to his level to kiss him hard and full upon th mouth. He looks at her dully, as though hardly conscious of it. she is back beside her mother. Martin rides away after th others.
(slowly) I almost hope they don't find them!
Laurie looks at her mother and understands.

The SEARCH THEME begins as we see the riders in turn. A series of portraits of the men. CLOSE SHOT - BRAD AND CHARLIE - riding point, they come t pause, surveying the terrain ahead. Charlie, with an arm  signal, indicates he will take the left. Brad nods and he rides out to the right. THE MAIN BODY OF THE MEN, Clayton passing first, expressi resolute, competent... Then Ed Nesby and old Mose, squint at the ground as they ride, all but sniffing like an old  hound dog.
MARTIN - Next to last in file. Finally:
ETHAN - His face a study of relentless purpose.

The two men are at a cairn of rocks -- their horses nearb In the near distance, Clayton is leading the men of the s party at a fast clip toward the cairn. Charlie is standin Brad tearing the rock cairn apart. In Charlie's hands is Comanche head-dress of polished buffalo horn and feathers Brad doesn't even look up as the men ride in and dismount but continues his grim work of uncovering the buried Indi
Another one, eh?
This 'un come a long way 'fore he  died.
Well, that's seven we can score up  to your brother, Ethan.
I don't like it.
What don't you like?

Injun's on a raid generly hides their  dead so you won't know how many  they've lost... If they don't care  about us knowin', it only spells one  thing... they ain't afraid of us  followin' -- or of us catchin' up  with 'em either.
You can back out any time, Nesby.
Didn't say that... (angrily indicating  Brad) What's he doin' that for...
He wants to be sure...
Brad shifts another rock and Looks grimly upon the face ( of the dead Comanche. Then he spits at it and stands.
(grim) Let's get along...
(to Brad) Why don't you finish the job?
With that he strides to the cairn, whipping a knife out. crouches over the body (O.S.) concealing what he is doing he bends to his bloody task. Sam Clayton crosses to stand behind him.
(gravely) What good does that do?
By what you preach... none!
He stands now and he faces Sam.
But by what the Comanche believe --  now he can't enter the spirit land,  but has got to wander forever between  the winds... because I took his mangy  scalp!

He flings the scalp down and grinds it into the dirt with his heel... He wipes clean the blade of his knife as he  crosses back to his horse. The men mount (those who have  dismounted) and they ride off.
Brad is looking out into the night -- strain and tension every line. Beyond them we may see some of the other men sitting or sprawled on the ground near a sheltered fire.
(a whisper) If only she's alive... I'll make it  up to her... No matter what's  happened... I'll make her forget...  She's just got to be alive...
Ethan crosses behind them carrying his blanket roll. He l at them sourly.
Get some rest!

They move off, heading for their blankets. The CAMERA HOL on Ethan as he rolls up his blanket and turns on his side He fishes a miniature out of his pocket and gravely studi it by the light of the flickering little fire.
It is a picture of Martha. The CAMERA PULLS BACK to show  Ethan studying it gravely, then putting it away and lying back to stare broodingly into the night.
The four faces are just over the ridge, peering at someth far distant, far below.
Could be a buffler...
It's horses, I tell ya...
It's them all right...
He starts to squirm down the ridge, the others following.
Ethan's group crosses to where the other men are waiting  with the horses.
They're camped by the river -- 'bout  twenty miles from here.  Soon's it  gets dark we'll circle out so's to  jump 'em before daybreak.
(slowly) You're right sure you want to jump  'em, Ethan?
Martin and Brad stare at Sam -- not understanding the  question. But Mose knows what he means and studiously loo into space.
(touch of defiance) It's what we're here for, ain't it?
I thought we were trying to get the  girls back -- alive... We jump those  Comanches, they'll kill 'em... You  know that!
(bewildered, angry) But... but what are we doin' then?... What are we supposed to do?
What I had in mind was runnin' off  their hoss herd... A Comanche on  foot is more apt to be willin' to  listen...
That makes sense to me.
Yeah...

(angrily) What do you know about it?... What's  a quarter-breed Cherokee know about  the Comanche trick of sleeping with  his best pony tied right beside him...  You got as much chance of stampedin'  their herd as...
...as you have of findin' those girls  alive by ridin' into 'em...  I say  we do it my way, Ethan... and that's  an order!
Yes, sir... But if you're wrong,  Captain Clayton, don't ever give me  another!
They look into each other's eyes a moment, then Sam turns mount... and the others follow. Slowly then they start ri down the slope.

(NOTE: It is now planned to shoot this on sound stage.) Fog and heavy morning mist rise from the swamp. Some catt in the near ground. The effect is eerie, very still excep for the trilling of frogs. Then, very quietly, the men em from the mist swirling around them. They are leading thei horses. Sam looks baffled, angry. They stand still, liste then slowly continue.
(SOUND STAGE)

The mist is thinning. In the f.g. is a small blackened ar the ashes of a campfire. The men come through the mist -- wary, vigilant. It is Mose who first spots the fire. He r to it and drops beside and feels the ashes. The others come up around him.
Ay-he... They was here...
(to Sam) SURE!... They WERE here... Now they're  out there... an' waitin' to jump  us!...
He looks at Clayton.
You got any more orders, Captain?
(quietly) Just keep goin'...
They move on, slowly.

The mist is thinning as the men warily move along. Suddenly there is the faint hoot of an owl from behind an to one side... the men turn slightly, hearing it... A mom later another owl hoot, from the same side but up ahead. From the interchange of looks, we must know that the ride are aware of its significance. Mose cups hand to his mout and he hoots in exact imitation of the other calls. Clayt glares at him.
(in soft apology) Jus' bein' sociable, Cap'n...
Ethan grins wryly. And now the first, faint, ruddy touch the sun hits the slowly moving horsemen and begins to bur through the mist.

The CAMERA SLOWLY PANS from a sun-touched butte or crag t the file of men slowly walking their horses. An occasiona shred of mist drifts by. Everything about the little cava bespeaks tension, watchfulness. Suddenly -- and every man sees it at the same time -- we see a file of eight Comanc ride slowly out of a canyon at a distance, walking their  horses at the same pace and on a course roughly parallel  with, but slightly converging on, our group.
(softly) Keep goin'...
Brad, who has been looking up ahead, sounds a new warning
(tensely) Look!
Easy!

Another Indian file of eight angles out of a different ca and begins to cut in toward the group -- riding slowly, v quietly. Clayton slightly alters course, veering slightly away from the converging files, but still riding slowly. then, from ahead but at a 100 yards, another Comanche gro seems to rise out of the ground and slowly begins closing the gap.
(to Clayton) If you were tryin' to surround 'em,  you sure succeeded.
How far's the river from here, Mose?
I been baptized, Reverend... yes  suh, been baptized, thank ye...
Well, you better brace yourself for  another one... Ya-HEE!
And with that yell, he drives spurs and cuts sharply at a angle to the converging Indian files -- and every man is  with him. In the next instant, the Comanches whoop and gi chase.
with the Ranger group short-cutting in such a way as to  outstrip the Comanche horsemen in a mad dash for the rive

Clayton flings his hand up in a signal to halt as the Ran reach the bank. They rein in, wheel their horses and are  reaching for the rifles as the Comanche vanguard races in view -- to find themselves opposed by seven veterans, sit their horses, rifles at their shoulders. The charge breaks as the seven rifles bark, almost in uni and the Indians wheel to shelter.
YA-HEE!
And once again he spins his mount and takes off, across t river, followed by the others.
As the men pound across.
They dismount and Charlie and Nesby take the horses and r them to some place of protection as the men group around  Clayton and Ethan. During this:
(shouting his orders) This is as good as any... Charlie,  you and Ed take the horses...

Mose runs over and crouches beside Ethan. Beyond Ethan is Martin, then Brad... Nesby and Charlie will rejoin the gr after an appropriate interval... with all the men shielde behind river boulders, etc.

location: ANGLING PAST ETHAN AND MOSE WITH MART

text: Ethan and Mose are hunkered down behind some rocks, very  casual and business-like as they check rifles, set out an carefully wipe cartridges.
(chattily) Minds me o' the time Joe Powers an'  me fit us some Kiowas...
Martin is in the throes of buck-fever, wiping mouth with  back of his hand, peering anxiously across the river.
You think they mean to charge us,  Uncle Ethan...?
...We found us an ole buffler  wallow...
(staring across river) Criminy!
On the opposite bank, we see the full force of Comanches  riding into sight -- racing their mounts to the edge, the wheeling off -- jeering, taunting. Brad starts to bring u his rifle.
Steady, Daniel Boone! You don't want  to miss... It makes them think their  medicine's stronger than yours...
Ay-he... That's jest what I tole Joe  Powers... That un's gettin' kinda  sassy, ain't he, Ethan?
One Comanche rides a few yards into the water, brandishin his rifle, taunting the white men. A moment later he is j by a second brave.
(grimly) Real sassy.

He and Mose slowly bring their rifles to bear -- and then the two shots crack out almost simultaneously. And within split seconds both Comanches fall. The others race away. Sam comes charging over to Ethan and Mose.
(angrily) I didn't give any order to fire!
That's all right, Captain... I don't  need any formal invitation to kill a  Comanch...
(grimly) You got one now!

And he drops behind a rock as, with a wild whooping, the  Comanche forces swing from their places of hiding and hit the river. The men open fire, all but Martin, who has fro staring wild-eyed at the oncoming Comanches.
Brad, Charlie, Clayton, Nesby are snapping shot after sho Only Martin seems out of it. Ethan shoots him a glance.
Slack your shoulders... Slack 'em...  Your hands'll take care of  themselves...
Some of the tension leaves Martin. Somehow his gun is in  position and he is firing as fast and well as the others.
The Comanches are coming in, crouched low over their poni necks, whooping and firing. Men and horses go down, count off by the expert marksmanship of the Texans. But they ke coming.

They drop their rifles now and pull out revolvers for clo range work. One Comanche breaks through from the side, hi buffalo lance ready for the thrust. Ethan whirls and fire The Comanche horse charges through the defense line and o and there is a muffled scream of pain from Ed Nesby.

The charge breaks and Comanches wheel left and right, rac back across the river. With magnificent horsemanship, one brave rides to an unhorsed warrior crouched in the shallo and swings him up behind. Two others, riding together, he for one of the two dead Comanches Ethan and Mose had down on their first shots. Swinging simultaneously from their  saddles, they grab the dead man and carry him off.
(cackling) There goes yer scalp, Ethan!...

Ethan snuggles his rifle to his shoulder as two other rac Comanches prepare to pick up the other dead Indian. Most the Comanches have regained the far bank now and are raci away. The firing from the Texans has stopped.
I still got one out there.
The angle is along his rifle barrel as it beads on one of the racing Comanches trying to pick up the dead Indian. Clayton's big hand grasps the rifle barrel.
(quietly) No, Ethan.
Ethan looks up into Clayton's face.
Let them bury their dead...
Ethan pulls the gun free and looks out across the river.
The Comanches have done their work, are riding away -- an over the saddle of one lies the limp form of the dead Ind Ethan looks back at Sam.
That tears it, Reverend... From now  on, you keep out... (mad now -- facing  the others) All of you!... I don't want you with  me... I don't need you... for what I  got to do!
(quietly) No need to shout, mister.
The CAMERA SWINGS to pick up the figure of Nesby outstret on the ground, writhing in pain; with Charlie kneeling be him. The men cross to stand around the fallen man.
Reckon we got to go back -- Ed's  shoulder is smashed -- bad!
I can make it... just get me on a  horse...
No good, Ed... And Ethan's right...   This is a job for a company of  Rangers... or it's a job for one or  two men... Right now we're too many...  an' not enough...
(facing Ethan) Only one way you can stop me lookin'  for Lucy, mister... An' that's kill  me...
That's how I feel, Uncle Ethan... (correcting the slip) Ethan, sir.
Ethan glares at them, but has to accept it.
All right... but I'm givin' the  orders... You take 'em or we split  up here and now...
(quickly) Why, sure, Ethan... There's just the  one thing we're after... finding  Deborah and Lucy...
(grimly -- turning  away) If they're still alive...
He heads away, for his horse. Brad and Martin look at eac other as the full import of Ethan's footnote strikes home Then they head for their own horses.
Ethan, Martin, and Brad mount. Clayton crosses to them.
You boys got enough shells?
They nod.
Yeah...
Vaya con dios.
The three re-enter the river and slowly start across, wit Clayton gravely looking after them. The three riders cont across the river... and the Search Theme resumes.

A region of buttes and giant rock formations; treeless, a and seemingly reaching out to infinity. Far off we see a  cloud of dust -- miles and miles off. Only the dust, noth else. From behind CAMERA ride the three men -- Ethan, Bra and Martin -- dust-powdered, eyes bloodshot. The three ar watching that distant cloud of dust. They force their wea horses onward.

The ANGLE is past some spectacular butte or citadel of ro into another long reach of valley -- different from the f view of it, yet alike in its suggestion of endlessness. But now there is no cloud of dust far away -- nothing to  suggest the passage of anything but time itself. Ethan, Martin, and Brad ride into the fringe of the butte shadow and scan the terrain ahead.
(shrill) They got to stop sometime... if  they're human at all, they got to  stop!
Naw... a human man rides a horse  till it dies... then he goes on  afoot... A Comanche comes along...  gets that horse up... and rides it  twenty more miles... Then he eats  it.
Ethan turns to catch Martin thirstily drinking from his  canteen.
(angrily) Easy on that!
Sorry... We don't even know if Debbie  'n Lucy are with this bunch... Maybe  they split up...
They're with 'em -- if they're still  alive.
Brad wheels on him.
You've said that enough!... Maybe  Lucy's dead... maybe they're both  dead... but if I hear it from you  again, I'll fight ya, Mr. Edwards!
(an aside) That'll be the day!... Let's ride.

(NOTE: This is the gap in the rocks near the "Medicine  Country" at Monument.) The three riders come to where the trail they have been  following forks... the main horseprint track leading ahea a lesser track heading for a narrow gap between two butte
Four of 'em cut out here... Why?
Ethan thinks he knows why. His face is bleak. But he trie to be casual.
I'll take a look... You keep after  the others...
He turns his mount toward the gap.
(eagerly) You want us to fire a shot if...
(disgustedly) No... nor build bonfires... nor beat  drums neither. I'll meet you on the  far side.

He's still grumbling as he rides off. An abashed Martin r ahead along the broad trail with Brad. (NOTE: Ethan's serape, tied behind his saddle, should be  clearly seen as he rides away -- not pointed up, but visi

Martin and Brad, riding in a direction opposite to that i which they had taken off -- indicating their circle route haul up momentarily as they spot Ethan, standing beside h horse, his back to them, some distance along. They turn  slightly off their course and ride out toward him.
Ethan turns, almost startled, as the two youths ride in. His serape is no longer behind his saddle. Ethan looks at them blankly for a minute -- as though not really seeing  them.
Oh... it's you.
They both stare at him.
(a vague gesture) I... uh... here's where they met up  again...
They both can see that.
(pointing) Trail leads off there...
They look at him and each other -- for these are clearly  unnecessary remarks and doubly surprising coming from Eth
Why'd they break off? (no answer) Was there water in that canyon?
Huh...?  No... no water.
You all right, Ethan?
Huh...? (more like his usual  gruff self) Sure I'm all right...
He goes to his horse, mounts. Martin is right beside him he notes the missing serape.
Say!... What happened to your blanket?  Lose it?
Must've... Anyway, I ain't goin'  back to look for it...
He leads out. Brad rides up beside Martin. Again the two  exchange puzzled looks. Martin shrugs and the three conti along the broad trace of the Indian ponies into the setti sun.

Ethan crouches over a small fire built into a slit trench that barely the glow of the flames can be seen. Beyond hi Martin is leading their unsaddled horses away. The men ha come to the end of another long day. Both men look up as  Brad comes over a hill slope and rides recklessly down th incline to their camp. His horse is lathered.
(shouting it) I saw her!... I saw Lucy!
Martin runs to his side as Brad slides off his mount. Ethan moves more slowly.
(continuing) They're camped 'bout two miles over... I was just swingin' back when I saw  their smoke... I bellied up a ridge  an' they was right below me...
Did you see Debbie?
No, but I saw Lucy all right... She  was wearin' that blue dress... an'  she was walkin' along...
(voice flat) What you saw wasn't Lucy.
It was, I tell you!

What you saw was a buck wearin' Lucy's dress... (they stare at him) I found Lucy back there in that  canyon... I wrapped her in my blanket  an' buried her with m'own hands... I  thought it best to keep it from you --  long as I could.
He can't look at Brad or at Martin. Brad can't speak -- a then finally:
Did they...? Was she...?
Ethan wheels on him in shouting fury.
(blazing) What've I got to do -- draw you a  picture?... Spell it out?... Don't  ever ask me!... Long as you live  don't ever ask me more!

Brad wipes his mouth with the back of his hand. He turns walking stiff-legged as though on stilts back to his hors He bends his head against the saddle, as though to hide h grief. Martin turns away from him and walks back to Ethan And in that moment, Brad mounts and takes off in the same direction from which he had ridden in.
(frantically) BRAD!...
They run for their horses.
He comes pounding down a slope, and he takes off his hat skims it away. He rips off a neckerchief as though to rel the rush of raging blood.

He reaches the crest and reins in. A distant firelight is his face. He takes one moment to look down into the Coman camp o.s. Then he has his gun out. His eyes are wild, his face wet with sweat. Then he throws back his head and he  yells -- and with the yell goes charging into the camp.

They rein in -- staring -- as from afar they hear Brad's  yell echoing and bouncing off the canyon walls. There is  nothing they can do. They hear his shouts, then the quick bark of his .44, and the angry shouts of the Comanche.
His face is red with the reflected light of the fires he passing o.s. and his eyes are alight with a crazy, savage joy. His gun cracks once, then again -- and the hammer cl on a spent shell.
He stands apart, warbow drawn and arrow notched. He relea it at his running target. We hear its impact and a high g of pain... and then the jubilant, yammering yells of othe Comanches.

The distant yammering of the Comanches doesn't quite drow out one stifled scream of pain; we can surmise a scalping knife was busy in the last instance of Brad's life. Marti slumps in his saddle. Ethan listens a moment, then turns Martin.
Let's just hope he took some with  him...
He turns his horse back the way they had come. Martin sta at him.
What you goin' to do?
Get some sleep... Tomorrow's another  day...
Slowly, he rides away. Slowly, reluctantly but helpless t do otherwise, Martin follows.

A study of horseprints etched in the soil -- the mark of passage of many horses; perhaps an eagle or turkey feathe fallen from a warbonnet. And then we hear and see the app of two plodding horses, and the dusty boots of the horsem Ethan and Martin -- following the trail. The Search Theme resumes and continues over the next three shots, helping suggest the passage of time, the change of scene.
The two figures are little more than specks in a vastness savage country.

Again we study the hooves of two horses, fighting their w up a rocky slope and past a thorn bush on which -- flutte in the mountain wind -- is a torn scrap of scarlet cloth  with a bit of beadwork or Indian decoration.

It is a portrait study of two faces -- etched by wind and privation and cold into tragic, fanatic masks. Martin has aged years in a matter of months. Falling snow flakes touch their faces and begin to rime their stubbly  beards.
(bitterly) Say it. We're beat!

(slowly) No... our turnin' back don't change  anything... not in the long run. If  she's alive, she's safe... for a  while... They'll keep her to raise  as one of their own, 'til she's of  an age to...
He turns his mount.
And you think we got a chance to  find her?

An Injun will chase a thing til he  thinks he's chased it enough... Then  he quits... Same when he runs...  Seems he never learns there's such a  thing as a critter that might just  keep comin' on... So we'll find them  in the end, I promise you that...  We'll find them just as sure as the  turning of the earth.

The time is spring. It is a year and a half later. The Jorgensen house is larger than the Edwards place -- o sod and logs, with a covered breezeway connecting the two separate buildings of the house: one being the keeping ro the other the sleeping quarters of the numerous Jorgensen brood. A meadowlark breaks into his sudden song. A dog or two come barking around the side of the house as Ethan an Martin ride slowly from behind CAMERA toward the house. I that instant a lamp is lighted within the house and Lars  Jorgensen comes to the door.

Jorgensen peers at the two men as they ride up - recogniz them, of course, but ill-prepared for the change in their appearance and full of unspoken questions. Bearing a lamp, Mrs. Jorgensen hurries out to stand besid her husband -- and her face works and tears begin to well her eyes. Two tow-headed boys -- 13 or 14 -- come after h Jorgensen makes a little signal with one hand, not even  looking at the boys, and they hurry out to take the reins Ethan and Martin dismount.

The passage of time has stamped Martin -- and will contin during our story more and more to stamp him -- in the ima of Ethan. Now it may show only in the set of his hat or t of standing; later it will be in his walk, in his speech paucity of speech). Neither man is sure of his reception. They are thinking of Brad -- dead because of their search and Martin is thinking of Laurie. And then Mrs. Jorgensen running across to Martin and has him in her arms as thoug he were her son -- saying nothing, just holding him. He s frozen a moment and then he returns the embrace. Ethan wa a moment, then crosses to Jorgensen.
(to Jorgensen) You got my letter about your son,  Brad?
Yah... Just about this time a year  ago...
It came the day before his...   birthday.
The Lord giveth--the Lord taketh  away...
Mrs. Jorgensen starts to lead the way inside. Martin hang back.
I ain't fit to go indoors, miz  Jorgensen... These clothes is...
Laurie rushes past her mother.
Martie!
She kisses him hard and full on the mouth -- and has no e for anyone else. Mrs. Jorgensen looks on with amusement.  Martin is just bowled over.
(teasing) And him probably forgettin' all about  you!... Probably can't even call  your name to mind.
(smiling) Laurie.
And Laurie smiles triumphantly at her mother.
(continuing) But I fairly forgot just how pretty  you was...
Laurie grabs his hand then and pulls him indoors -- and t is no further resistance from Martin. Mrs. Jorgensen and her husband converge then on Ethan -- her face is gravely questioning.
The little one?... Debbie?
Ethan shakes his head. She squeezes his arm reassuringly they start indoors.

location: THE SPARE BEDROOM OF THE JORGENSEN'S

text: This is a room off the kitchen end of the keeping room -- and described in the book as the "grandmother room": with narrow, slit-like windows, a set of single bunk beds, pos a fireplace. Martin is in a deep wooden tub, taking a hot bath, curryi his back with a long-handled brush. Beyond him is the doo It opens and Martin turns casually -- and at once stops b casual as Laurie enters and purposefully crosses to a sto or bench on which his discarded clothing is scattered.
Hey... What you doin'...?
She picks up the shirt, puts it over one arm; she reaches for his long-handled and ragged underwear, runs a fist th a hole in its seat, clucks and shreds it into rags. Durin this:
(a yelp) Don't go takin' that stuff...
Ain't worth the mendin'...
She turns and looks at him, matter of fact.
What you gettin' red-in-the-face  for?... I have brothers, haven't I?
Well I ain't one of 'em!

I'm a woman, Martie... (he tries to say  something but she  goes right on) We wash and mend your dirty clothes  all our lives... When you're little  we even wash you... How a man can  ever make out to get bashful in front  of a woman I'll never know...
You talk like a feller might just as  leave run around nekkid...
Wouldn't bother me... (she heads for the  door) I wouldn't try it in front of pa,  though, was I you...
And she is laughing as she closes the door behind her.

location: THE KEEPING ROOM OF THE JORGENSEN HOUSE

text: It is a plastered room, everything bright and shiny; a bi wood-burning cookstove, above it a row of shiny copper po the furniture handmade and probably not too much unlike t good plain Swedish modern of today. There should be Scandinavian accents in the decor. All to a cheerful, warm-smelling room. Ethan is talking as Laurie enters the room still carrying Martin's shirt, the rags of his underwear. She will wait, listening for a break in what Ethan is saying, to try to her mother's attention. Jorgensen is sitting in his usual chair -- with his boots off, puffing his pipe more or les in tune with what Ethan is talking about. Mrs. Jorgensen in her rocker, darning or knitting. Ethan is standing nea the mantel.

...an' then it snowed and we lost  the trail... No need to tell ya all  the places we went... Fort Richardson,  Fort Wingate an' Cobb... the Anadarko  Agency... Trouble is we don't even  know which band that war party  belonged to...
Mrs. Jorgensen looks up from her darning.
Well, you did all a body could, Ethan.
I got your boy killed.
(gently) Don't go blamin' yourself...
(angrily) It's this country killed my boy!...  Yes, by golly!
Mrs. Jorgensen stands.

Now Lars!... It so happens we be  Texicans... We took a reachin' hold,  way far out, past where any man has  right or reason to hold on... Or if  we didn't, our folks did... So we  can't leave off without makin' them  out to be fools, wastin' their lives  'n wasted in the way they died... A  Texican's nothin' but a human man  out on a limb... This year an' next  and maybe for a hundred more.  But I  don't think it'll be forever.  Someday  this country will be a fine good  place to be... Maybe it needs our  bones in the ground before that time  can come...
The speech impresses everyone but Laurie, who probably ha heard a word of it.
Ma!... Martie's drawers is a sight!   Ain't fit for rags!... Would it be  all right if we gave him some of  Brad's things?
There is just the briefest hesitation...
Why...'course it would! They're in  the chest...
And she leads the way briskly, with Laurie following, to big chest at the far end of the room.
(rising excitedly) By golly, the letter... In the chest,  mama... It came for you, Ethan...   last winter...
Ethan and Jorgensen cross together to where Mrs. Jorgense is raising the top of a huge dower chest. She extracts a  letter, wrapped in oilskin against moths.
(continuing) Joab Wilkes of the Rangers brought  it...

Ethan takes the letter and studies it very carefully befo venturing to open it. Jorgensen is quite curious, but try not to seem nosy. The women remain at the chest -- pullin out various folded garments, etc. Finally Ethan carefully opens it and takes out a letter -- dirty as to paper, cru printed in pencil and with a horseshoe nail pinning a two inch square snip of calico to the bottom of the sheet. He reads the letter with the habitual difficulty of a man un to words and then he turns the letter, removes the nail a looks at the snip of cloth.
(quietly) Mrs. Jorgensen...
She comes to him, her arms piled with clothing; and Laurie a step behind her, holding up a new pair of long- handled underwear -- measuring it with her eyes for holes etc.
Will you look at this?
He holds out the snip of calico.
Why it's just a snip of calico...
You ever see it before... like mebbe  on a dress Debbie wore?
Yes!... Yes, I remember!... Have  they found her, Ethan?
No... not yet...
He takes the calico snip, places it within the letter and carefully pockets it. He looks broodingly into the fire.
(continuing) ...not yet...
Laurie's face is troubled as she turns from him and heads for the grandmother room, carrying the armful of clothes.
Martin is sitting sulkily on a cot, wrapped in a blanket. He glares up as Laurie enters. His feet are in his boots.
Might at least have left me my pants!
Shush!... Time for bed anyway... (putting clothes near  him) Likely these'll need some takin'  in... Oh, Martie, you're that gaunted!  ...Ma's havin' a turkey for dinner  tomorrow and...
(calling) Laurie!... Come... come!
Ethan opens the door, enters.
Yes, Pa!... Good night, Martie...   good night, Mr. Edwards...
She wants to kiss Martie but is shy in Ethan's presence a hurries out.
Good night... Laurie...
Good night...

Martin stoops to remove his boots. Ethan studies him and  looks thoughtfully after the girl and at Martin. He takes the letter out of his pocket -- as though he mea to read it -- and then he puts it back decisively. He starts to undress. Martin lies back on his bunk.
Jorgensen's been runnin' his cattle  with my own...
(staring) YOUR cattle?... DEBBIE'S cattle!
Ethan returns the stare without any change of expression.
He's agreed to take you on and share  the increase from my herd while I'm  gone... I'll be pushin' on tomorrow...
I ain't stayin'... I set out lookin'  for Debbie... I aim to keep on...
Why?
Because she's my... my...
She's your nothin'... She's no kin  to you at all!
I always felt like she was... Her  folks takin' me in, raisin' me like  one of their own...
That don't make 'em kin...
All right... I ain't got no kin...   I'm goin' to keep lookin' that's  all.
How? You got any horses, or money to  buy 'em... You ain't even got money  to buy cartridges... Jorgensen's  offering you a good livin' here...
Martin throws himself back, turns his face to the wall. Ethan looks soberly at him -- and is sorry for the brutal of his words.
Martin... I want you to know  somethin'...
(turning -- mad as  hell) Yeah... you want me to know I ain't  got no kin -- no money -- no horses --  nothing but a dead man's clothes to  wear!... You tole me that already...   Now shut your head!
Good night.
It is a still scene, with the first light of day in the s a thin plume of smoke rising from the chimney.

She is in a robe made of an Indian blanket, belted snugly around her waist. She wears moccasins for slippers. Her  flannel nightgown is high at the collar and almost trails the floor. She is at the stove, frying bacon and eggs; a  coffee pot is on the boil. Beyond her the door to the  grandmother room opens and Martin comes in -- dressed in  Brad's clothes. His eyes whip around the room. Laurie doe turn as he slowly approaches.
(quietly) Ethan rode on... an hour ago.
The starch goes out of him. He walks heavily to the table and sits, slumped. She looks at him compassionately.
I don't know what you can do about  finding Debbie that he can't...
He just shakes his head, not looking at her. She lifts th food from the skillet onto a plate and sets it before him
He'll find her now, Martie... Please  believe me... I know.
He shakes his head. She crosses to the stove for the coff pot.
That's what scares me -- him findin'  her.
Now it is her turn to stare.

Laurie, I've seen his eyes when he  so much as hears the word 'Comanche'  ...I've seen him take his knife an'  ...never mind... But he's a man can  go crazy wild... It might come on  him when it was the worst thing could  be... What I counted on, I hoped to  be there to stop him, if such thing  come.
Laurie has poured his coffee. Now he sips it. She sits at the table with him.
(slowly) I hoped I could hold you here... But  I guess I knew... So I stole this  for you...
She takes Ethan's letter from her breast and hands it to  him. He takes it, puzzled, and slowly reads it aloud.
'I bought a small size dress off a  Injun... If this here is a piece of  yr chiles dress bring reward. I know  where they gone... Jerem Futterman.'
Martin is on his feet.
(excited) Futterman!... He's got a little  tradin' post on the South Fork o'  the Brazos... Laurie, I just got to  get me a good horse! Think yer pa  would...
Finish your breakfast...
I gotta catch up with him, Laurie!
(almost in tears --  but angry) Go on then! Pa's in the barn saddlin'  the Fort Worth stud... an' you can  take the light gelding with the  blaze...
But that's Sweet-face -- your own  good horse.
Laurie goes to the front door and throws it wide.

(hysterically) Take it and welcome... but don't  count on finding me here when you  get back... I've been dallying around  this god-forsaken wind-scour almost  two long years waitin' for you... I  ain't cut out to be an old maid!
(miserably) I can't help it, Laurie... I just  gotta catch up with Ethan...
He runs out and she slams the door, then rests her head  against it.

Mrs. Jorgensen quietly enters the room and sees Laurie wi head pressed against the door. She wants to offer some wo of sympathy, but doesn't know what to say. She crosses to the stove to pour herself a cup of coffee. Then we hear t drum of horses' hooves, the sound of Martin riding away. Laurie flings open the door, almost as though to call him back.

location: PLAINS COUNTRY AND LAKE BEFORE JORGENSEN HOUSE

text: ANGLING from behind Laurie in the doorway as Martin, ridi one horse, leading another, goes galloping away.
Low, squat adobe structure, with a crudely lettered sign- board proclaiming it: 'JEREM. FUTTERMAN, TRADER'

There are adjacent outbuildings and corral. Four horses a tied outside, two being pack animals. A surly-looking whi man or breed sits in a stool tilted back near the door,  whittling with a long-bladed knife, eyeing the horses  covetously. He glances aside and glares as a squaw shuffl along bearing a clumsy load of faggots on her bowed back.
Andale! Andale!
Fearfully she quickens her step. The man gets up, shoves  knife into belt and heads into the post.

It is a grimy establishment with some dusty trade goods o shelves; a counter which serves as a bar; a few plank tab and benches. The breed seen outside enters and crosses to a side table where another mean-looking hombre sits preparing to play game of solitaire with a deck of limp cards. Ethan and Martin are at a table in the center of the room examining a dirty, rumpled child's dress -- Debbie's. Martin nods soberly in answer to Ethan's inquiring look;  yes, it's hers. Both look up as FUTTERMAN crosses from th bar, carrying a whisky jug and two dirty glasses -- his  fingers thrust inside the glasses. Futterman is a squaw m and a killer -- dead eyes in a white face.
Drink?

He sets the jug down, picks up one of the glasses -- so g and thumb-printed it is almost opaque. Both Ethan and Mar regard it with disgust. Futterman gives a slight shrug, t the dress and starts to wipe the dirty glass with it. Mar snatches it out of his hand.
(harshly) How'd you come by this?
You said there'd be a thousand dollar  reward.
That's what I said.
You got it with you?
Ethan looks at him and beyond toward the two men.
The solitaire player has a card in mid-air -- frozen,  watching. The other man has the same buzzard-watchful loo
Reward'll be paid when I find her --  an' if she's alive...
Futterman uncorks the jug, prepares to drink.
Man's got a right to expect some  kind o' payment... I laid out for  the dress an' sendin' you the  writin'...
He tilts the jug to his mouth as Ethan reaches for his he leather pouch. Futterman watches greedily as Ethan lets a gold piece slide out. He tosses it onto the table.
Twenty Yankee dollars.
Futterman puts the jug down. His hand inches -- as though pulled by a magnet -- toward the gold piece.
...an' a man's time is worth  somethin'...
Ethan's big hand clamps over Futterman's and he starts  squeezing as a man would squeeze a lemon. Futterman's lip whiten.
Talk!
A young buck fetched it in late last  summer... (Ethan eases the grip) Said it belonged to a captive chile  of Chief Scar...
Scar? Never heard of any Chief Scar.
Me neither... But this buck claimed  he was a big war chief with the  Nawyecky Comanches.
Keep talking.
Scar's band was headin' north... to  winter in at Fort Wingate... eatin'  agency beef. That's what this buck  said... Maybe he lied.
And maybe you lie...
In that case you won't find her -- and I won't get my thousand dollars.
Ethan stands. Martin follows. Martin takes the dress and  folds it carefully.
(too casually) Stay the night if you want... (Ethan shakes his  head) Cards?... A jug?... If you'd like  some company, we got a few squaws on  the place...
Ethan and Martin head for the door.
No thanks.
The two plug-uglies stand -- mean ready to do their maste bidding.
Don't forget to come back with my  thousand dollars.
Ain't yours yet.
They leave. The CAMERA holds on Futterman as he slowly ru his bruised hand. His henchmen drift toward him.
(slight smile) Bad manners... He shoulda said 'good- bye.'

They have set up camp near a cluster of cottonwoods to wh the horses have been tied. One of the horses is restless, possibly nickering. Ethan strokes its neck, looking out  thoughtfully into the night -- listening.
Acts like somethin's out there.
(heading toward  campfire) Smells a change in the weather...
CAMERA PANS him to where Martin is spreading his blanket  some little distance from the small fire.
Wouldn't surprise me if we didn't  have a frost 'fore mornin'... Here... (he picks up a saddle  and puts it close to  fire) Whyn't you bed down closer to the  fire, boy?

Martin is a bit surprised as Ethan takes the blanket and  spreads it near the saddle -- making the saddle serve as pillow. Then Ethan tosses a few more heavy pieces of dry  wood on the fire, making it blaze up.
Hey! What's the idea...?
Maybe I'm gettin' like Mose Harper --  my bones is cold tonight...
He spreads his own blanket as Martin wraps into his bedro and when Martin turns, he casually arranges the blanket t suggest it is over the figure of a man. During this:
Funny... When we passed through Fort  Wingate last winter, we didn't hear  mention of any Nawyecky Comanche  there...
Ethan steps back -- and studies the "dummy."
Not so funny... if you recollect  what 'Nawyecka' means...
What's that?
Ethan studies Martin's back -- the light on him -- and lo around figuring the range of fire.
Sorta like 'roundabout' -- like a  man says he's goin' one place when  he means to go just the reverse...
(drowsily) Oh...
You all settled an' comfortable now?

Martin just grunts and snugs deeper into his blanket. Eth nods his satisfaction -- sure Martin isn't going to chang positions. Then he takes off his hat and boots and uses t to complete the dummy. He picks up his rifle then and qui walks out of the camp.
